speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument next in Case 14-510, Menominee Indian Tribe of Wisconsin v. the United States. Mr. Strommer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Are you talking about the Ramah?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And -- and that was a -- a decision, unpublished decision by a district court. It never went any further.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: The issue --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: The issue that that case settled or addressed was whether exhaustion was required at all. Minimal research would have shown that every other court at that time who had addressed the issue had required exhaustion. Now, we'll go later to exhaustion-when. That's a separate question. So how could you reasonably rely on a lower court decision that hasn't gone through the crucible of appellate review without having done any research on whether its premises were subject to dispute, reasonable dispute, and rely on that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But they raised the Alderson Reporting Company argument just lost. They raised the argument that the exhaustion requirement didn't meet the commonality prong of class certification. So they did make an argument against it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I know that's what you believe, but every other court up until that time had said no, you needed to exhaust. Now, we can go to a separate question of exhaust-when later. But how could you at that point rely on that case to think that you didn't have to --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Strommer --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- all of this goes to deciding whether the legal advice they received was reasonable legal advice. I find that quite irrelevant. Do you have a single case in which legal advice has qualified for equitable tolling?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So you're really -- you're really arguing a -- a remarkable proposition, that if you get bad legal advice, that justifies equitable tolling.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You -- you mentioned extraordinary circumstances, but our -- our cases refer to extraordinary circumstances that stood in the way and Alderson Reporting Company prevented timely filing. I -- I would not qualify erroneous legal advice as preventing time -- timely filing. I don't care how reasonable it was. It didn't prevent it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You -- you want us to -- to limit our principle of erroneous legal advice justifies erroneous equitable tolling only in class-action cases?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But you're limiting it to class actions. You -- you don't want to -- why -- why should it be limited to class actions? I mean, if --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- if erroneous legal justifies equitable tolling, why should it be limited to class actions?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That prevent -- that prevent the test prongs at all.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But -- but if legal advice prevents tiling -- timely filing in class-action situations, I don't know why bad legal advice doesn't prevent tile -- timely filing in every other situation as well. I -- I just don't -- it -- it's sort of a weird -- a weird rule. Just -- just for class actions?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What was the length of time between the denial of class certification and --  and the presentment? It was a long time, wasn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So why was that due diligence --  I mean, I know that we're not arguing about due diligence, but it seems to me that, when there was --  certification was denied in the Cherokee case, you had two years to present and you would have been home free. You would not have encountered a time bar. Two years. But you, in fact, didn't present until four years after the denial in the --  in the Cherokee case. So how was that due diligence?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But the class action is over. It's been denied.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The class action has been denied.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So at that point you know you're on your own. You can't piggyback on the class. You know you're on your own, and yet you let two years go by. I don't understand that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Actually --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- that's not quite true. There's a circuit split which hasn't been addressed anywhere in the briefing. Some of the circuits do it the way you say. They stop the clock and restart the clock at the end of the tolled period. In those circuits you would win. You could wait the entire six years plus however long the other case was pending. Alderson Reporting Company But another series of circuits looked to diligence throughout the period. And so you'd be asking us to make an assumption about which -- or make a decision about which tolling applies. You are taking a risk no matter what you did.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, let's go back to Justice --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- Scalia's question ask you a question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: All of these decisions, were they made with the advice of a lawyer? And I have a sense that the Tribe was concerned about its resources and that they were just getting together and talking about this and deciding, we're not going to win under the law, so we're not going to file. And it was only when Cherokee Nation was decided by this Court that they realized they had a Alderson Reporting Company viable claim. So -- but answer my question: Was there legal advice sought?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: If we disagree that that was -- if we think that was unreasonable, what -- your reading of what class counsel said, what would happen?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But it has not been found by a single district court, right? I mean, you're saying that that single district court should have had such power in the Tribe's mind that they didn't do the presentment. And that -- that seems an extraordinary thing. It's just a single district court. A single Alderson Reporting Company district court has no controlling authority over anyone or anything other than that particular decision.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: They benefitted, but the point is there is one court that says your Tribe can be a member. Your --  your Tribe didn't present its claim to the contracting officer. And so why can they be a member? The judge addresses that question, and he says, normally they couldn't be a member, but they can here because this is the kind of case that is attacking general practices of the administration. Alderson Reporting Company Then okay. Fine. You got that. Then shortly after that or maybe a few years after that, another case comes along. And the other case doesn't involve the situation of attacking the practices generally. It concerns the individual contracts between the Tribe and the Indian Bureau, what -- you know, in the government. And there they say, you can't have a class action. So you'd think -- and this kind of case you want to bring now is the second kind, not the first kind. So you'd say, why is it fair to let you bring this case? After all, if you'd read the opinion closely in the first one, you wouldn't have thought you should have waited. If you had any doubts about it, the second one would have told you you should have waited. And even beyond that, the administrator signs a piece of paper where they ask him: Do you have any claims under these contracts? And he says, none. So it doesn't seem to me you're talking about pure equities; you have very strong grounds. Now what's your reply to that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You probably wouldn't agree Alderson Reporting Company with any of them. But -- but -- but --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You're not making that kind of claim here, are you? I mean, you're not challenging the general practices of the government. Rather, you're challenging the particular contracts and whether you got enough money under them. Is that right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: If that's correct --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, then the fact that the second case emphasized the general --  you know, the general attack, which lacks in your case, is more reason for thinking that we better file our claims quickly because what had --  they held in those two cases are not going to help us, who have an individual claim. We better do what the statute says or the rules, and we better file our presentment to the contracting officer and certainly not write the words "none" when they ask you if you have any claim; am I right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But wait. I just want to clarify one point. On this issue of -- that you were a member of the class, you rely just on counsel's letter in the first case, in Ramah, the letter that -- where counsel described the class and said there would be --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: No, in the prior case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: No, no, no, no, no. You said that the lawyers had told you that there would be class action tolling. That was the general --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But you haven't answered my question. That's the only advice from a lawyer you received.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Alderson Reporting Company Ms. Eisenstein.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: How did it know that, in Cherokee Nation? He claims that the only decision was on --  under Rule 23, and that presentment and tolling was not at issue there.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, let's talk about the American Pipe tolling. It would seem to me, as has happened in a number of litigations, that at the time that the complaint is filed, it doesn't mean that every member of the class has to have exhausted, because if that's what it means, then there can never be a class action.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: All right. So that Alderson Reporting Company issue is still open under the law, because it would seem to me, and I could be wrong, that if you still have time on the clock when the complaint is filed, that you can --  before you receive any remedy under the class action suit, you can present --  exhaust then, and recover, if you've done it during the period that --  the six-year period plus tolling. That's what some courts have done. They've defined the class as people who have exhausted, or who still have time to exhaust.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, this is a slightly different argument. You're saying they can't get equitably tolled for exhaustion of the administrative process.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Even if they could get tolled for filing a lawsuit.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Can you explain something in -- in your brief that would seem to make all of this beside the point? You several times referred to a release form that covered the years in question. And it's in the appendix at Pages to If the -- if there was a release covering those years, then why does anything else matter? Why isn't the release -- they release the claims for those three years?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Did the Indian Health Service have the authority to require the Tribe to release those claims during the contract closeout process?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What would have happened if they refused to sign the release?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So it turned out there were consequences after all.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Are there any circumstances Alderson Reporting Company in which reliance on legal advice could constitute the extraordinary circumstance required for equitable tolling?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That it's settled in all circuits. They've all ruled one way. You don't think it's reasonable to give advice based on that ruling, that that might be an exceptional circumstance?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So how about it's not Alderson Reporting Company 13, it's 12, but you're in a circuit that hasn't ruled. You mean that it's --  it wouldn't be an extraordinary circumstance in that situation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That's one circuit. I'm talking about the vast majority.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: out of

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Fair. Fair answer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Was the government harmed in any way by the -- the lack of presentment?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The D.C. Circuit said this is presentment, this is just paperwork, easy -- easy to do. But the Tribe couldn't -- if they had presented to the contracting officer, they just couldn't leave it at that. They would have to take an administrative appeal within days, or they'd have to appeal to the Federal circuit within a year. So more was at stake for this Tribe than simply filing a piece of paper.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Alderson Reporting Company You have nine minutes remaining, Mr. Strommer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: There -- there are so many people who don't have resources to pursue a litigation. How do we differentiate you from those Alderson Reporting Company millions of people with lack of resources who choose not to pursue claims, either because they think, at least up till then, they're going to lose, because that's the state of the law, or for whatever other reason they're waiting? How --  how do we --  how do we articulate an equitable tolling principle that won't open a floodgate to making a statute of limitations basically a nullity?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: If it was reasonable, why didn't you litigate that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Why didn't you take the order of the --  the court below, that --  and appeal that order?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: To seek cert. on that question?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: When there was no split. But you had a split.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: When your decision came up.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
